channel.title: NYT > World

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Reform, Ahoy? A Newspaper Heralds New Horizons for the Chinese Ship of State
item.description: A day before a top-level political meeting opens in China, a prominent newspaper highlights widespread calls for extensive reform, including social and political change, in a hefty special supplement.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The Beijing News's 96-page report is titled: "Reform: Setting Off Again."

item.title: 40 Years On, No Foul Play Found in Chilean Poet’s Death
item.description: A driver for Pablo Neruda, the Nobel-winning poet who died weeks after a coup ousting Salvador Allende, had alleged he was given a mysterious injection.
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: The Lede: Lara Logan’s On-Air Apology for Flawed Benghazi Report
item.description: Video of the CBS News correspondent Lara Logan apologizing for her flawed “60 Minutes” report on the deadly assault on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, last year.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Late to the Race, but Early to the Finish Line
item.description: Sim Jae-duk, a South Korean shipyard worker, has run 210 amateur marathons since 1999 and has been dubbed the “Korean Forrest Gump.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Despite working five to six days a week at the shipyard Sim Jae-duk runs at least three marathons a month. He showed off his daily strength-training in his home in Okpo, off the southern port of Busan.

item.title: Kerry Joins European Officials at Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Geneva on Friday amid rising expectations for an accord that would freeze Iran’s nuclear program, though he said “important gaps” were yet to be bridged.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and the European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, before their meeting with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif on Friday in Geneva.

item.title: Powerful Typhoon Causes Mass Disruption in Philippines
item.description: Typhoon Haiyan has killed at least four people and forced the evacuation of hundreds of thousands.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: High waves crashed into the sea wall on Friday as Typhoon Haiyan hit the city of Lagaspi, the Philippines.

item.title: CBS Correspondent Apologizes for Report on Benghazi Attack
item.description: Lara Logan, a correspondent for a “60 Minutes” segment on the attack on the United States Special Mission in Libya, said the news division was misled.
item.dc:creator: By BILL CARTER and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: The CBS News correspondent Lara Logan apologized Friday morning for mistakes in a segment on "60 Minutes" last month about the attack on the United States Special Mission in Benghazi, Libya.

item.title: 2 Dead After Car Bomb Blast in Somali Capital
item.description: A police officer in Somalia says two people were killed after a car bomb exploded next to a hotel frequented by government officials.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Palestinian Investigator Blames Israel in Arafat’s Death
item.description: Though conceding there was not enough evidence that Yasir Arafat was poisoned with a radioactive substance, Palestinians said Israel was the main suspect.
item.dc:creator: By SAID GHAZALI and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Syrian Opposition Group Backs Out of Talks With Government Officials
item.description: The meeting planned for Moscow would have brought the main Syrian exile opposition group and government officials together for the first time.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 8
item.description: Prince Charles and his wife Camilla Parker-Bowles, Duchess of Cornwall, are on an official visit to India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Camilla Parker-Bowles, Duchess of Cornwall with Prince Charles, Prince of Wales, outside the Akshardham Temple in New Delhi during an official visit to India.

item.title: U.S. Loses Voting Rights at Unesco
item.description: The move came because Washington stopped paying dues two years ago in protest over admission of the Palestinians as a full member of the United Nations agency.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Balancing Act for India’s Top Banker
item.description: Raghuram Rajan is cutting interest rates to stimulate growth, while talking tough against India’s high inflation rate.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Chiara Goia for The New York Times
item.media:description: Raghuram Rajan has led India’s top bank since Sept. 4.

item.title: India Ink: Story Behind a Stapled Chinese Visa
item.description: The writer was not allowed to board a scheduled flight to China, where he was headed to pursue graduate studies, as his Indian passport had a stapled visa.
item.dc:creator: By ASGAR QADRI
item.media:description: Manmohan Singh, left, prime minister of India, with Li Keqiang, premier of China, in Beijing, China, on Oct. 23.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New Twist in War Between Industrial Heavyweights
item.description: The tangled and storied conflict between China’s two biggest heavy-equipment makers is getting renewed scrutiny amid a culture of hacking and corporate espionage.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Indian Ambassador to Afghanistan Amar Sinha
item.description: Mr. Sinha talks about the perils of living in Afghanistan and why that will not stop India from expanding its soft power in the region.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Amar Sinha, Indian ambassador to Afghanistan.

item.title: Jews in Europe Report a Surge in Anti-Semitism
item.description: Nearly a third of European Jews have considered emigration because of safety fears, according to a new survey, which suggests that prejudices are spreading to new segments of society.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: As Plenum Starts, an Economist Sees Crisis Ahead
item.description: China faces a crisis unless big economic changes are accompanied by a political overhaul, a respected Chinese economist says as Communist Party leaders prepare to meet on the nation’s economic future.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wu Jinglian, 83, at his home in Beijing.

item.title: Strongest Typhoon of the Year Slams Philippines
item.description: One of the most powerful typhoons ever recorded slammed into the Philippines Friday, cutting communications and blocking roads in the center of the country amid worries of serious damage and casualties.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Under Strain, France Examines Its Safety Net
item.description: The pervasive presence of government in French life, from workplace rules to health and education benefits, is now the subject of a great debate.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: SOCIAL PROGRAMS RUN DEEP: St.-Étienne, a midsize French city, has deep working-class roots and a population that depends on government benefits.

item.title: Outsider’s Victory in Portugal Reflects Continent’s Discontent
item.description: Rui Moreira, 57, achieved a rare political victory in Western Europe by being elected the mayor of Porto, Portugal, without having been affiliated with an established political party.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: João Pedro Marnoto for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rui Moreira, 57, the newly elected mayor of Porto, Portugal, ran on a decidedly local reform agenda.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Storm Hits East Coast
item.description: The United States Navy’s Joint Typhoon Warning Center in Hawaii said the typhoon, Haiyan, had maximum sustained winds of 195 miles per hour, with gusts up to 235 m.p.h.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Blasts Kill at Least 30 People
item.description: In the largest attack, two suicide bombers targeted an Iraqi military base north of Baghdad late Thursday, killing 22 soldiers and wounding at least 45 others, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Rejected Seat on U.N. Panel Is Considered by Jordan
item.description: Arab states are said to be conducting talks about which country might replace Saudi Arabia in a nonpermanent Security Council role.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Nazi War Criminal Buried at Jail
item.description: The body of Erich Priebke, a former SS captain, has been buried in an anonymous grave in an abandoned cemetery in an Italian prison, the newspaper La Repubblica said Thursday.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
